statement.p:
Consider the vectors
\vvec=\fourvec203{-2}, \hspace{24pt} \wvec=\fourvec1{-3}41.
Find the lengths of the vectors \len{\vvec} and \len{\wvec}.
Find the dot product \vvec\cdot\wvec and use it to find the angle \theta between \vvec and \wvec.

Consider the three vectors
\uvec = \threevec1{-2}2, \hspace{24pt} \vvec = \threevec111, \hspace{24pt} \wvec = \threevec02{-1}.
Find the dot products \uvec\cdot\uvec, \uvec\cdot\vvec, and \uvec\cdot\wvec.
Now find the following quantities:
\len{\uvec}.
(-5\uvec)\cdot\vvec.
\uvec\cdot(-3\vvec+2\wvec).
\len{\frac1{\len{\uvec}} \uvec}.
For what value of k is \uvec orthogonal to k\vvec+5\wvec?

Suppose that \vvec and \wvec are vectors where
\vvec\cdot\vvec = 4, \hspace{24pt} \wvec\cdot\wvec = 20,\hspace{24pt} \vvec\cdot\wvec=8.
What is \len{\vvec}?
What is the angle between \vvec and \wvec?
Suppose that t is a scalar. Find the value of t for which \vvec is orthogonal to \wvec+t\vvec?

Suppose that \wvec=3\vvec.
What is the relationship between \vvec\cdot\vvec and \wvec\cdot\wvec?
What is the relationship between \len{\vvec} and \len{\wvec}?
If \vvec=s\wvec for some scalar s, what is the relationship between \vvec\cdot\vvec and \wvec\cdot\wvec? What is the relationship between \len{\vvec} and \len{\wvec}?
Suppose that \vvec=\threevec{3}{-2}2. Find a scalar s so that s\vvec has length 1.

Consider the vectors
\vvec_1=\threevec204,\hspace{24pt} \vvec_2=\threevec{-1}2{-4}.
and a general vector \xvec=\threevec xyz.
Write an equation in terms of x, y, and z that describes all the vectors \xvec orthogonal to \vvec_1.
Write a linear system that describes all the vectors \xvec orthogonal to both \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.
Write the solution set to this linear system in parametric form. What type of geometric object does this solution set represent? Indicate with a rough sketch why this makes sense.
Give a parametric description of all vectors orthogonal to \vvec_1. What type of geometric object does this represent? Indicate with a rough sketch why this makes sense.

Explain your responses to these questions.
Suppose that \vvec is orthogonal to both \wvec_1 and \wvec_2. Can you guarantee that \vvec is also orthogonal to any linear combination c_1\wvec_1+c_2\wvec_2.
Suppose that \vvec is orthogonal to itself. What can you say about \vvec?

Suppose that \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3 form a basis for \real^3 and that each vector is orthogonal to the other two. Suppose also that \vvec is another vector in \real^3.
Explain why \vvec=c_1\vvec_1+c_2\vvec_2+c_3\vvec_3 for some scalars c_1, c_2, and c_3.
Beginning with the expression
\vvec\cdot\vvec_1 = (c_1\vvec_1+c_2\vvec_2+c_3\vvec_3)\cdot\vvec_1,
apply the distributive property of dot products to explain why
c_1=\frac{\vvec\cdot\vvec_1}{\vvec_1\cdot\vvec_1}.
Find similar expressions for c_2 and c_3.
Verify that
\vvec_1=\threevec121,\hspace{24pt} \vvec_2=\threevec1{-1}1,\hspace{24pt} \vvec_3=\threevec10{-1}
form a basis for \real^3 and that each vector is orthogonal to the other two. Use what you've discovered in this problem to write the vector \vvec=\threevec35{-1} as a linear combination of \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3.

Suppose that \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3 are three nonzero vectors that are pairwise orthogonal; that is, each vector is orthogonal to the other two.
Explain why \vvec_3 cannot be a linear combination of \vvec_1 and \vvec_2.
Explain why this set of three vectors is linearly independent.

In the next chapter, we will consider certain n\times n matrices A and define a function
q(\xvec) = \xvec\cdot(A\xvec),
where \xvec is a vector in \real^n.
Suppose that A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 2 \\ 2 \amp 1 \\ \end{bmatrix} and \xvec=\twovec21. Evaluate q(\xvec) = \xvec\cdot(A\xvec).
For a general vector \xvec=\twovec xy, evaluate q(\xvec) = \xvec\cdot(A\xvec) as an expression involving x and y.
Suppose that \vvec is an eigenvector of a matrix A with associated eigenvalue \lambda and that \vvec has length 1. What is the value of the function q(\xvec)?

You most likely know that the equation of a line in the plane can be written in the form y=mx+b, where m is the slope of the line and b its vertical intercept. In this exercise, we'll develop a new way to write the equation of a line.
We are interested in describing the blue line.
Write an equation in the form y=mx+b for the line shown in .
Suppose that \pvec is a point on the line, that \nvec is a vector perpendicular to the line, and that \xvec=\twovec xy is a general point on the line. Sketch the vector \xvec-\pvec and describe the angle between this vector and the vector \nvec.
What is the value of the dot product \nvec\cdot(\xvec - \pvec)?
Explain why the equation of the line can be written in the form \nvec\cdot\xvec = \nvec\cdot\pvec.
Identify the vectors \pvec and \nvec for the line illustrated in and use them to write the equation of the line in terms of x and y. Verify that this expression is algebraically equivalent to the equation y=mx+b that you earlier found for this line.
Explain why any line in the plane can be described by an equation having the form Ax+By = C. What is the significance of the vector \twovec AB? Notice that this form enables us to describe vertical lines, which cannot be written in the form y=mx+b.
Consider the two lines
2x + y \amp {}={} 3
x + 2y \amp {}={} 3.
Find their point of intersection and find the angle between them.
